content:
Why is there a 0 as the second line in all cases?
It's not mentioned in the stub generator, so it's just a weird artefact.

I just got this in Reverse and it was very distracting.
It seems like it's just a hacky way to make your C++ solution work without knowing the number of inputs... ahh, that's what it is. It's just a way to avoid defining the number of inputs... hmm. Not ideal.
Your XOR trick is cool but is an unfair advantage for lvl 20+ codingamers who can see the solution. So huge advantage in shortest :/

I like your xor trick, I just solved it by adding to / removing from a set.
Please make sure that the testcases don't have a whitespace at the end of the line, that makes "Console.ReadLine().Split().Select(long.Parse)" crash.
I recommend to change the input format: line1 = number of integers, line2 = the integers.
That would also help to fix my next concern: you did not provide a stub generator for the input parsing.
And make the limit for N a little smaller, maybe 10^7 (you can't have that many numbers anyway, but python/javascript would struggle with the performance here).
The values for k are larger than necessary too, 10^15 is still big enough to prevent a bool[] as valid solution. JS only has double, so a hashset<string> would probably be the best approach here for k<=10^18.
Why can't I see any game modes? Is that a clash that neither is fastest nor shortest nor reverse?

Whoa. You're not actually giving a testcase with N = 1000000000?! Seems pretty big for input, eh?

Also, the limit for k = 10^18 doesn't add much to the challenge, and limits languages.

TL;DR weird constraints.
Yeah, it's just to force people to think instead of just bruteforcing with array. At least they will use a set / map.

Oh sorry, i'm quite noob creating problems.
I reduced input to N<10^4, and i will let the k<=10^18 because it does not matter.
Anyway, N<10^4 still theoretical because i can't really use that number of characters in input.
Yeah, probably it is, but i expect most people to don't look to the solution until they solve the problem.
Maybe. But next time please try not to put your best solution here :)
you forgot on in the last validator , i removed it
I know i'm not using 10^9 inut because i can't paste all that numbers. But numbers up to 10^18 it's to force people to avoid using an array.
I think 10^18 will not limit languages, you can use unsigned long long / big int, or use a set with strings.
